data.title: dropped support for relative paths in launch.json: UX problems
data.body:
When using old launch.jsons with relative paths, VSCode throws warnings into the users face.
I don't think that we can ship with this in January.
- the warning doesn't specify what attributes are affected, instead I see only the value that I will have to fix. Since the fix has already been applied to the value, it is difficult to locate the value in the lunch.json.
  ![2015-12-22 13-48-36](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/11955516/d9c076b6-a8b2-11e5-9eef-c71b204361b5.png)
- "${workspaceRoot}/." (and variants) look a bit silly. This is just "${workspaceRoot}"
- Sometimes it is impossible to figure out what to do. This launch.json looks OK but VSCode still complains that there is a "." somewhere. I couldn't spot the error: ![2015-12-22 13-40-40](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1898161/11955595/80af0a32-a8b3-11e5-991d-26a406536855.png).

In general I think that we should not show warnings in this way because it is annoying and unhelpful. Instead we should show warning (later "error") squigglies in the json editor and offer intellisense to help the user inserting the missing "${workspaceRoot}" and have a "light bulb" action for fixing the whole launch json (as an example use the validation that got introduced for the Keyboard Shortcuts json).

If this is not possible for January, I suggest that we only fix our intellisense, templates, samples, etc. but show no warnings in the launch.json editor.

data.title: Task and/or Extension Command User Arguments On Entry

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am creating an extension and I want the end user to be able to enter an argument (say string) at the step they select "Run Task". The only current workaround I can think of is informing the user to edit the tasks.json file with the arguments, but what I am asking/requesting is that they could enter a one time use argument at the point they call the task from the command pallet, for instance Run Task, then My Task --My Argument. I am having the same issues with extension commands. To my knowledge there is no way to get a user argument into an extension command at the point of execution from the command pallet. 

See my stack overflow on this topic here:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34382899/visual-studio-code-user-defined-argument/34385950?noredirect=1#comment56564014_34385950

data.title: If a file is already open in a tab, don't open it again when clicking the file explorer

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This is a UX issue but let's say I have two files open and my cursor is on the right tab:

```
+-------------------------+
|   File 1   |  *File 2   |
+-------------------------+
```

if I click on `File 1` in the file explorer, I end up with something like this:

```
+-------------------------+
|   File 1   |  *File 1   |
+-------------------------+
```

This is probably useful in some scenarios but most often it's not. Then I have to click on top of the tab and select the `File 2` manually to end up with what I had before.

I suggest that if a file is already open in a tab, you don't load it in the active tab but simply change the active tab to the file that is open:

```
+-------------------------+
|  *File 1   |   File 2   |
+-------------------------+
```

data.title: Crashing when editing user preferences

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I'm seeing a lot of crashes and hangs in 0.10.5 when editing user preferences (and a few other hangs here and there when editing regular files). 

I can repro this quite easily so if there's any help you need getting some logs/data locally just let me know. Repro steps usually are:
1. Open vscs
2. Open File\Preferences\User settings
3. Edit user settings file - copy from template, paste into user settings, keep copy and pasting
4. vscs hangs, eventually get a not responding from Windows

I've seen a few other hangs here and there when editing regular files but I can't really tell if they're related. 

Here are my version stats

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7736961/11951716/7f073a12-a893-11e5-8043-fe17b8123425.png)

data.title: Debugger adapter's "runtimeArgs" parameter is ignored

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I am trying to use native ES6 features like `Promise` and `Map` in my debug adapter.   To enable these features, I've created this configuration for my debugger extension:

```
    ...
    "contributes": {
        "debuggers": [
            {
                "program": "./out/DebugSession.js",
                "runtime": "node",
                "runtimeArgs": ["--harmony"],
    ...
```

However the `--harmony` parameter never seems to make it to the command line of the launched code subprocess, so it fails upon encountering ES6 features in the code.

Could I suggest, adding ctrl-~, but cycling between all associated files (that is, files with the same name, but different file extension).

data.title: Support menu bar visibility toggle also on Linux (fixes #1563)
Add support for hiding the menu bar also on Linux
data.body:
Issue #945 was closed with commit c34d2e771bb3e372e912e081a8bd8879a92a8c91. The commit added the requested option to add an option for toggling visibility of the main menu, but restricted it to be shown only when running the Windows version.

I can see why toggling the menu bar probably would either not work or just not make sense on OS X. Users running Linux window managers that have a menu bar per window would benefit from the setting as much as users of the Windows version though.

data.title: [css] Remove deprecated CSS colorKeywords
data.body:
When completing CSS values, there is a very long list of named colours, keywords, functions, etc. Included are a whole host of CSS System Colours, which have been deprecated for a long time. 

“Earlier versions of CSS defined several additional named color keywords, the <deprecated-system-color>s, which were meant to take their value from operating system themes. These color names have been deprecated, however, as they are insufficient for their original purpose (making website elements look like their native OS counterparts), and represent a security risk, as it makes it easier for a webpage to "spoof" a native OS dialog.” – https://drafts.csswg.org/css-color/#system-colors

While it is easy to skim read through the named colours, these system colours hide some of the more valuable values, such as transparent and currentColor. 

As the system colours are deprecated, arguably of little value, and probably not used very much, should we remove them from the completion list?

data.title: The 'ext install' command is unavailable after compiling from the sources

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I compiled the VSCode as described [here](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute#build-and-run-from-source). After that I have created the `code` script with the following content:

```
(cd /some/path/vscode/src/scripts && ./code.sh)
```

and made it executable:

```
chmod +x /usr/local/bin/code
```

After that when I run the VSCode, hit Ctrl-Shift-p and type `ext install` I see the 'No extensions found' message, please see the attached file.
![vscode bug](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9556817/11943974/21af2cc0-a853-11e5-90d2-f22a6ae37c17.png)

When I type the `extension` I see the only 'Extensions: Show Installed Extensions' message, please see the next attached file.
![vscode bug1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9556817/11944040/b4bf7db2-a853-11e5-9036-a54ede1e8604.png)

Expected behaviour: show the 'Extensions: Install Extension' item in the list or suggest to install an extension.
Actual behaviour: empty list or the only one 'Extensions: Show Installed Extensions' item.

---

OS: Arch Linux, 64-bit

Debugging via "Launch" works fine and breakpoints are hit.
OS: Windows 10
Node version: v4.2.2
Project created via Visual Studio 2015 with NTVS -> New Project->Templates->Other Languages->JavaScript->Basic Node.js Express 4 Application

data.title: Localized keybindings mismatched
data.body:
The "navigateBack" command is listed in my config file as:

```
{ "key": "ctrl+alt+-",            "command": "workbench.action.navigateBack" }
```

I am using the German keyboard layout with Visual Studio Code. I get a tooltip over "ctrl+alt+-" telling me to press "ctrl+alt+ß" instead (the ß key of the German keyboard is at the position of the - key on the English keyboard)

However, the command I actually have to press in order to navigate backwards is ctrl+alt+-, using the - key of the German keyboard, which is somewhere else entirely.

Thus, the tooltip is incorrect while the key as it is stated in the config file is correct.

Edit: my operating system is Linux x64 (Ubuntu 14.04)
